G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 209, § 37 (if applicable); and its general equity jurisdiction in matters concerning custody, parenting time, and the welfare of minor children.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 37.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 209, § 37 (if applicable); and its general equity jurisdiction in matters concerning custody, parenting time, and the welfare of minor children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify a judgment relative to custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment and where modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, the Court must consider the best interests of the child as the paramount concern in determining custody, including the past and present parental cooperation, capacity to meet the child’s needs, and willingness to support the child’s relationship with the other parent.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a custody or parenting judgment may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare and when modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and turns entirely on the ‘cause shown’ / best interests standard for authorizing removal where parents share joint legal and physical custody. It does not discuss the general standard for modifying custody or parenting plans based on a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances,’ nor does it state that such a change plus best interests is the test for modification. The only mention of ‘substantial change in circumstances’ appears in a quotation from the ALI Principles about relocation, not as a statement of Massachusetts appellate courts’ consistent modification standard.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]… (4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”}

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a custody or parenting judgment may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare and when modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of alimony and child support, not custody or parenting-time. It articulates the standard for modifying support orders (“material change of circumstances”) but does not discuss modification of custody or parenting judgments, nor the child’s best interests as a standard for changing custody. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about custody/parenting modifications.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a custody or parenting judgment may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare and when modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The case discusses the standards for making an initial custody award in a divorce (focusing on the children’s best interests and welfare) and the trial judge’s discretion in choosing between sole and joint custody. It does not concern or mention modification of an existing custody or parenting judgment based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. Because no post-judgment modification standard is addressed, the case does not support the claimed proposition about when modification is permitted.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a custody or parenting judgment may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare and when modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case expressly declines to apply or discuss the custody‑modification standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, because that theory was not raised below and was therefore waived. The opinion instead analyzes an initial custody determination under the “best interests of the child” standard in § 10(a) and does not address when or how an existing custody or parenting judgment may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances. Thus it provides no authority for the proposition about the standard governing modification of prior custody or parenting judgments.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a custody or parenting judgment may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare and when modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and initial custody decision, not a modification case. It discusses best interests of the child and standards for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, but it does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting judgment, nor does it articulate a requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances as a prerequisite to modification. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child….”

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a custody or parenting judgment may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare and when modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely invokes G.L. c. 208, § 28 and recites the standard that a custody judgment may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and when modification is necessary in the children’s best interests. Although the case primarily concerns removal, the court corrects the trial judge’s misunderstanding by expressly reaffirming this two-part modification standard, citing prior appellate authority, thus supporting the proposition about consistent Massachusetts appellate holdings.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 ("Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children").

McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurring opinion focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and relocation/removal issues, not on the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting judgment. It references best interests and stability in passing (via Custody of Kali), but does not itself articulate or apply the two-prong "material and substantial change in circumstances" plus "best interests" modification test. *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ("If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...")."

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Defendant’s repeated disparagement of the Plaintiff to the Children and his blaming of the Plaintiff for missed activities interfere with the Children’s emotional security, place them in the middle of adult conflict, and are inconsistent with the best-interests standard articulated in *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, *Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, and *Cabot v. Cabot*, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 756.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses domestic violence and its effects on a child’s emotional well‑being and best interests, but it does not address parental disparagement of the other parent, blaming the other parent to the child, or placing the child in the middle of adult conflict through such disparagement. Its holding focuses on the need for explicit findings on the impact of domestic violence when making custody decisions, not on verbal denigration or interference with emotional security in the specific way described in the proposition. Thus, *Custody of Vaughn* does not directly support the specific disparagement-based best‑interests proposition cited.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm… There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence… Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication.”

It does not address parental disparagement, exposing children to adult conflict, or the best-interests analysis from Custody of Vaughn or Cabot. Nothing in the reasoning discusses a parent’s blaming the other parent to the children or the emotional security of the children, so using this case for that proposition misstates its holding and scope.
*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, despite the statutory prohibition against retroactive modification of child support judgments … a judge may — in certain very limited circumstances — grant and apply such an equitable credit to offset a child support arrearage accrued during a period when there was no pending complaint for modification.”
